# Bivariate: Association between 2 variables

## Naming conventions

|      Response      |     Explanatory      |
|:------------------:|:--------------------:|
|         y          |          x           |
|      outcome       |      predictor       |
| dependent variable | independent variable |
|                    |      covariate       |
|                    |       feature        |

\

Model notation: $y \sim x$

## Types of combinations

-   Categorical response and categorical explanatory variable. (C \~ C)
-   Quantitative response and categorical explanatory variable. (Q \~ C)
-   Quantitative response and quantitative explanatory variable. (Q \~ Q)

#  {background-image="images/penguins.png" background-size="60%"}


::: {.cell}

:::


## Categorical response & Categorical explanatory

::: panel-tabset
### Two way tables (cross-tabs)

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
table(pen$species, pen$island)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
           
            Biscoe Dream Torgersen
  Adelie        44    56        52
  Chinstrap      0    68         0
  Gentoo       124     0         0
```
:::
:::

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
table(pen$species, pen$island) |> prop.table(margin=2) |> round(2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
           
            Biscoe Dream Torgersen
  Adelie      0.26  0.45      1.00
  Chinstrap   0.00  0.55      0.00
  Gentoo      0.74  0.00      0.00
```
:::
:::

:::
:::

-   All of the 52 penguins on Torgersen island are the *Adelie* species.
-   74% of penguins on Biscoe island are *Gentoo*.

### Plots


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](lec05-describing_relationships_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::

:::

## Watch your margins {.smaller}

::: panel-tabset
### Tables

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
**Row Percents**


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
           
            Biscoe Dream Torgersen
  Adelie      0.29  0.37      0.34
  Chinstrap   0.00  1.00      0.00
  Gentoo      1.00  0.00      0.00
```
:::
:::


29% **of *Adelie* penguins** are on Biscoe Island.
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**Column Percents**


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
           
            Biscoe Dream Torgersen
  Adelie      0.26  0.45      1.00
  Chinstrap   0.00  0.55      0.00
  Gentoo      0.74  0.00      0.00
```
:::
:::


74% **of penguins on Biscoe island** are *Gentoo*.
:::
:::

### Plots

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
Distribution of islands for each species


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](lec05-describing_relationships_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


29% **of *Adelie* penguins** are on Biscoe Island.
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
Distribution of species on each island.


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](lec05-describing_relationships_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::


74% **of penguins on Biscoe island** are *Gentoo*.
:::
:::
:::

## Quantitative response & Categorical explanatory {.smaller}

::: panel-tabset
### Grouped summary statistics

Mean, median, sd, IQR of the quantitative variable for each level of the categorical level.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
pen %>% group_by(species) %>% 
  summarize(mean = mean(bill_depth_mm, na.rm = TRUE), 
            median = median(bill_depth_mm, na.rm = TRUE), 
            sd = sd(bill_depth_mm, na.rm = TRUE), 
            IQR = IQR(bill_depth_mm, na.rm = TRUE))
```
:::

::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 3 Ã— 5
  species    mean median    sd   IQR
  <fct>     <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
1 Adelie     18.3   18.4 1.22   1.5 
2 Chinstrap  18.4   18.4 1.14   1.90
3 Gentoo     15.0   15   0.981  1.5 
```
:::
:::


Gentoo penguins have lower average bill depth compared to Adelie or Chinstrap (15.0mm vs 18.3 and 18.4mm respectively). Chinstrap however have a larger IQR at 1.9 compared to 1.5 for the others.

### Plots

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
**Overlaid density plots**


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
gghistogram(pen, x = "bill_depth_mm", fill = "species", add_density = TRUE, add="mean")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](lec05-describing_relationships_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**Side by side boxplots**


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggviolin(pen, x="species", y = "bill_depth_mm", color = "species", add = c("mean", "boxplot"))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](lec05-describing_relationships_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::

:::
:::

The distribution of bill depth are fairly normal for each species, with some higher end values causing a slight right skew for Adelie and Gentoo.
:::

## Quantitative response & Quantitative explanatory

::: panel-tabset
### Summary statistic


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
cor(pen$flipper_length_mm, pen$body_mass_g, use="pairwise.complete.obs")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[1] 0.8712018
```
:::
:::


The penguin flipper length (mm) has a strong positive correlation with body mass (g), r=0.87

### Plots

::: columns
::: {.column width="50%"}

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggscatter(pen, x="flipper_length_mm", y = "body_mass_g")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](lec05-describing_relationships_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggscatter(pen, x="flipper_length_mm", y = "body_mass_g", add = "loess", conf.int = TRUE)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](lec05-describing_relationships_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=960}
:::
:::

:::

<small> The relationship between flipper length and body mass in penguins is relatively linear, but there may be possible clustering on a third variable. There appears to be two groups below and above a flipper length of about 205mm. </small>
:::
:::

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {

      // dispatch for htmlwidgets
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for reveal
    if (window.Reveal) {
      window.Reveal.addEventListener("slidechanged", function(event) {
        fireSlideChanged(event.previousSlide, event.currentSlide);
      });
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
